Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Evolutionary Significance of Skeletal Variation in Homo naledi

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The recent discovery of the hominin species Homo naledi has introduced new complexity and new questions about human evolution. In this doctoral dissertation project, the investigator will use 3D scanning technology to quantify skeletal variation across a number of H. naledi individuals and situate the results in a broader comparative primate context. Beyond providing an evolutionary context for the variation in H. naledi, this project will highlight the relationship between genetic and skeletal variation at multiple scales, which may be used to identify related individuals within bioarchaeological, forensic, and paleoanthropological assemblages. The research will generate hundreds of 3D models of three primate species, which will be made available to the public, creating new educational materials that can be 3D printed and used for lesson plans and outreach. Additionally, through close collaborations with local and international universities, undergraduates with interests in 3D imaging will continue to engage in independent research projects using these scans.<br/><br/>It is not known whether the recently discovered H. naledi individuals represent part of a small, isolated population or a larger, geographically diverse species that may have interacted with modern humans. In this project, the variation between H. naledi individuals will be quantified using 3D geometric morphometric assessment of five postcranial elements. Comparative modern human and chimpanzee samples containing individuals of known and unknown biological relationships will be used as baselines to explore variation at multiple scales. To this end, this project has three objectives: 1) to test the hypothesis that there is a positive relationship between genetic and morphological distance at and below the population level in modern humans and chimpanzees; 2) to quantify the variation within H. naledi and compare it to the variation calculated for modern humans and chimpanzees; and 3) to contextualize this variation by determining the extent to which H. naledi resembles biological relatives. A number of evolutionary scenarios concerning population isolation and relative size will be evaluated to determine which scenario most likely produced the variation seen in H. naledi. In so doing, this project will shed light on H. nalediâ€™s evolutionary history and the possibility of interaction between H. naledi and modern humans.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2013 discovery of an extinct human relative, Homo naledi, from the Dinaledi Chamber in Rising Star Cave in South Africa has complicated our current understanding of human evolution. H. naledi?s ancient skeletal characteristics are at odds with the relatively young age of the fossils (approximately 300,000 years old), there is little evidence for how or why they entered the cave, and the 15 skeletons that were found together look surprisingly similar to one another, with very little variation between individuals. Attempts to retrieve DNA from the fossils have been unsuccessful thus far, making it difficult to determine the biological relationships between these individuals and the nature of the deposition itself.

In this project, we assessed skeletal shape variation in H. naledi and its two closest living relatives?modern humans (H. sapiens) and chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes)?to determine whether signatures of close genetic relatedness can be detected from skeletal remains. We used individuals that were known biological relatives or came from the same reproductively isolated community and compared them to global, species-level samples to evaluate whether the relatives exhibited less skeletal shape variation than non-relatives. Upon completion of this study, we will be able to determine whether the variation exhibited by H. naledi from the Dinaledi Chamber most closely resembles that of close biological relatives, a population, subspecies, or species. This may provide further insight into the timeframe over which these individuals may have entered Rising Star Cave by constraining their deposition to a few generations or less, and shed light on H. naledi?s evolutionary history.

We used a geometric morphometric approach using 3D models of five bones: one in the hand, one in the leg, and three in the foot. These were among the most frequently encountered and best preserved bones in the H. naledi sample. We 3D scanned hundreds of these bones from the H. naledi, modern human, and chimpanzee samples, which involved travelling to six skeletal collections housed at museums and universities within the United States and in South Africa and Europe. While analyses are still ongoing to explore the effects of ancestry and other variables, preliminary results show that in humans, biological relatives do exhibit significantly less variation in two bones of the foot than non-relatives. This pattern held even when controlling for differences between the sexes. Notably, the related chimpanzee sample exhibited significantly less variation in four out of the five bones than the species-level sample.

Together, these preliminary results suggest that biological relatives can be skeletally distinguished from non-relatives in both modern humans and chimpanzees in multiple regions of the skeleton. This work contributes to ongoing research that aims to understand when, how, how often, and why H. naledi entered Rising Star Cave. Due to H. naledi?s relatively small brain, this larger body of work has implications for what behaviors we attribute to extinct species and may redefine what we consider ?modern.? Beyond providing an evolutionary context for the variation in H. naledi, this project highlights the relationship between genetic and skeletal variation at multiple scales, which may be used to identify relatives within forensic, bioarchaeological, and other hominin assemblages in the absence of DNA.

This project has also produced over 500 surface scans of three primate species. With permission from the home institutions housing the collections, these scans will be uploaded to the online digital repository MorphoSource at the conclusion of the project, where they will be available to the public free of charge for use in educational and research-related endeavors. Additionally, several undergraduates from Duke University and North Carolina State University were trained on 3D imaging techniques over the course of this project. Finally, an NSF-INTERN supplement to this grant allowed the Co-PI to pursue a non-academic science communication internship at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, where she developed skills such as interviewing scientists and translating their research into accessible content for public audiences. The Co-PI now works as a full-time science communicator for a non-profit research institute dedicated to improving human health, international development, and more.

Modified by: Amanda N Rossillo

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The 2013 discovery of an extinct human relative, Homo naledi, from the Dinaledi Chamber in Rising Star Cave in South Africa has complicated our current understanding of human evolution. H. naledi?s ancient skeletal characteristics are at odds with the relatively young age of the fossils (approximately 300,000 years old), there is little evidence for how or why they entered the cave, and the 15 skeletons that were found together look surprisingly similar to one another, with very little variation between individuals. Attempts to retrieve DNA from the fossils have been unsuccessful thus far, making it difficult to determine the biological relationships between these individuals and the nature of the deposition itself. In this project, we assessed skeletal shape variation in H. naledi and its two closest living relatives?modern humans (H. sapiens) and chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes)?to determine whether signatures of close genetic relatedness can be detected from skeletal remains. We used individuals that were known biological relatives or came from the same reproductively isolated community and compared them to global, species-level samples to evaluate whether the relatives exhibited less skeletal shape variation than non-relatives. Upon completion of this study, we will be able to determine whether the variation exhibited by H. naledi from the Dinaledi Chamber most closely resembles that of close biological relatives, a population, subspecies, or species. Beyond providing an evolutionary context for the variation in H. naledi, this project highlights the relationship between genetic and skeletal variation at multiple scales, which may be used to identify relatives within forensic, bioarchaeological, and other hominin assemblages in the absence of DNA. Finally, an NSF-INTERN supplement to this grant allowed the Co-PI to pursue a non-academic science communication internship at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, where she developed skills such as interviewing scientists and translating their research into accessible content for public audiences. The Co-PI now works as a full-time science communicator for a non-profit research institute dedicated to improving human health, international development, and more.
